column2: And it does so by focussing on the meaning of the relevant words, in
this  case  clause  3(2)  of  each  of  the  25  leases,  in  their  documentary,
factual and commercial context. That meaning has to be assessed in
the light of (i) the natural and ordinary meaning of the clause, (ii)
any other relevant provisions of the lease, (iii) the overall purpose
of the clause and the lease, (iv) the facts and circumstances known
or  assumed  by  the  parties  at  the  time  that  the  document  was
executed, and (v) commercial common sense, but (vi) disregarding
subjective evidence of any party's intentions”.  [emphasis added]

In Wood  v.  Capita 
Insurance  Services  Limited (supra),  which

column1: language used and the commercial context in which a clause was drafted
when deciding between competing meanings of a clause.  The Supreme
Court held, at para 10 that:

column2: “The court’s task is to ascertain the objective meaning of the language
which the parties have chosen to express their agreement. It has long
been accepted that this is not a literalist exercise focused solely on a
parsing of the wording of the particular clause, but that the court must

consider 
the  contract  as  a  whole  and,  depending  on 
the  nature,
formality and quality of drafting of the contract, give more or less weight
to elements of the wider context in reaching its view as to that objective
meaning.

whether the Appellant, can be properly characterised as a “travel agent” or
